awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021:  Investigating the potential role of coral-associated microbes in regulating calcifying fluid chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The Fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. Marine calcifying organisms, such as corals, are threatened by ocean acidification (OA), caused by changes in seawater chemistry that result from increasing levels of carbon dioxide. It is important to understand, in order to predict, how marine organisms respond to environmental changes (such as increasing temperatures) in this era of climate change. A critical factor in the response of corals and other marine calcifying organism to OA is their ability to regulate the chemistry at the site where calcification happens. Symbiotic coral microbes provide numerous services to their host. For example, some coral symbiotic bacteria can protect the coral host from pathogens. Some non-symbiotic microbes can help the formation of calcium carbonate minerals. However, it is unknown whether symbiotic microbes can play a similar role. The objective of this research project is to investigate whether symbiotic microbes of coral help these coral with calcification. Throughout the duration of the fellowship, the fellow will also work towards broadening participation of groups underrepresented in biology at the postdoctoral level by leading a book club for the WHOI post-doc community.

This interdisciplinary project, which integrates carbonate chemistry and microbial metagenomic analysis, aims to contribute significantly to our understanding of (1) how marine calcifying organisms (specifically Astrangia poculata) regulate the chemistry at their site of calcification and (2) how host-associated microbial communities may contribute to the health and resilience of their host. This project will also (3) shed new light on the debated topic of whether or not coral endosymbiotic algae play a role in calcification. In addition to working on this project, the fellow will lead a book club with the aim of helping participants learn about and discus the experiences of traditionally underrepresented groups of scientists and assess what we can do as individuals to make underrepresented minorities feel included within our community. The book club has potential to improve retention of underrepresented groups at the post-doctoral level by training allies that will assist in creating an inclusive environment, thereby improving the experiences of post-docs from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Biomineralization, the process by which animals like corals and oysters build shells and skeletons, is a critical part of ocean ecosystems, yet many of the biological details remain unknown. This project explored a new and exciting idea: that microbes living inside animals may help regulate the chemistry of the internal fluids where shell formation occurs. While the original proposal focused on corals, this research shifted to using Eastern oysters (Crassostrea virginica) as a more accessible model organism to answer the same fundamental questions.

Over the course of the fellowship, I collected fluid samples from inside live oysters and analyzed the microbial communities living in this unique internal space. Using a combination of DNA and RNA sequencing (metagenomics and metatranscriptomics), I identified microbial genes involved in carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur cycling, which are processes that could influence how calcium carbonate, the building block of shells, forms. To understand how microbial activity responds to changing conditions, I also conducted a controlled tidal-cycle experiment that simulated natural fluctuations in seawater chemistry while monitoring both microbial and host gene expression.

The results revealed that microbial gene expression in the calcifying fluid was more responsive to internal, host-driven changes than to external seawater chemistry. This suggests that the oyster may regulate its internal environment in ways that influence not only shell formation, but also the microbes living in that space. In turn, those microbes may help maintain favorable conditions for biomineralization.

Beyond advancing our understanding of marine life, this research has broader implications for fields such as climate change biology, aquaculture, and coral reef conservation. As ocean conditions continue to change, it is important to understand how animals build and maintain their shells, and how microbial partners may support their resilience.

In addition to scientific research, this project emphasized public engagement and creative science communication. I shared the findings not only through publications and academic seminars, but also through a performance at the Unfiguring Conference, where I used dance as a medium to explore and express the dynamics of host–microbe interactions. I also mentored undergraduate students and research interns, contributing to workforce development in biology and microbiome science.

Overall, this fellowship laid the foundation for a new research direction that explores how animal–microbe partnerships shape the formation of shells and skeletons. The insights gained during this project will support continued research into the biology of marine calcifiers and the invisible microbial communities that help them thrive.
